pullRequest.body:
Add some basic lemmas stating that a Cauchy filter in a discrete uniform space is principal.

Co-authored-by: María Inés de Frutos Fernández @mariainesdff 

---

nodes.body: @PatrickMassot Did you find the time to have another look at my modifications following your suggestions?

Sorry, I didn’t have time. But I gave my last lecture of the year this morning so I thought I would celebrate my new free time with another round of review. I see you didn’t fully understood my comment about using the ultrafilter API. Also I should have said that using pure instead of principal and singleton would unclutter things.

The whole story can be:
```lean
/-- A Cauchy filter in a discrete uniform space is contained in a principal filter-/
theorem Cauchy_Discrete_le_principal {X : Type _} {uX : UniformSpace X}
    (hX : uX = ⊥) {α : Filter X} (hα : Cauchy α) : ∃ x : X, α = pure x := by
  rcases hα with ⟨α_ne_bot, α_le⟩
  rw [hX, bot_uniformity, le_principal_iff, mem_prod_iff] at α_le
  obtain ⟨S, ⟨hS, ⟨T, ⟨hT, H⟩⟩⟩⟩ := α_le
  obtain ⟨x, rfl⟩ :=
    prod_subset_idRel_Eq_singleton_left (α_ne_bot.nonempty_of_mem hS) (Filter.nonempty_of_mem hT) H
  exact ⟨x, α_ne_bot.le_pure_iff.mp <| le_pure_iff.mpr hS⟩

/-- A constant to which a Cauchy filter in a discrete uniform space converges. -/
noncomputable def Cauchy_Discrete_constant {X : Type _} {uX : UniformSpace X}
    (hX : uX = ⊥) {α : Filter X} (hα : Cauchy α) : X :=
  (Cauchy_Discrete_le_principal hX hα).choose

theorem Cauchy_Discrete_le {X : Type _} {uX : UniformSpace X} (hX : uX = ⊥)
    {α : Filter X} (hα : Cauchy α) : α = pure (Cauchy_Discrete_constant hX hα) :=
  (Cauchy_Discrete_le_principal hX hα).choose_spec

/-- If a filter is not `⊥` and less than two pure filters then the corresponding points are equal.-/
theorem _root_.Filter.NeBot.eq_of_le_pure_le_pure {X : Type _} {α : Filter X} (hα : α.NeBot) {x y : X}
    (hx : α ≤ pure x) (hy : α ≤ pure y) : x = y :=
  pure_injective (hα.le_pure_iff.mp hx ▸ hα.le_pure_iff.mp hy)
```

But the last lemma must move out of this file and go to `Mathlib.Order.Filter.Ultrafilter`. I am also not super happy with the names in the main part. I don’t think this is really following the naming convention.

### PR summary [21b2f0d38f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/12179/commits/21b2f0d38f4c376aae266d533160607319965bc5)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ DiscreteUnif.cauchy_const`
`+ DiscreteUnif.cauchy_const_eq`
`+ DiscreteUnif.cauchy_le_pure`
`+ eq_of_le_pure`
`+ prod_subset_idRel_Eq_singleton`
`+ prod_subset_idRel_Eq_singleton_left`
`+ prod_subset_idRel_Eq_singleton_right`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

Thanks! I have incorporated your changes, changed the names and moved the last one to the relevant file.

One thing that I find a bit unsatisfactory is the doc about principal and pure filters, though. As a matter of fact, since pure filters do not exist in the litterature (only principal ones), one is tempted to use `principal` more than `pure`. The doc saying `s ∈ pure a` is defeq `a ∈ s` (showing that this definition is somewhat better, as exemplified by your review, is not in the doc for principal ones but for pure: even worse, at the beginning of the basic file on filters only `principal` is mentioned, nothing appears about `pure`. I would argue that some more doc instructing to use `pure` instead of `principal` could be added, and actually ask if principal filters are needed altogether (or if the definition can be refactored to only have the definition as in `pure`, perhaps renamed `principal`). What's your opinion about all this?
Do you really need the left and right versions after proving the stronger version?
Well, I use the left to prove the right and both to prove the full one. For my application I only need the left (for example) but I find it more complete to have the three.
All those `𝓟 idRel` should be spelled bot. And the conclusion should be an equality. Is there any reason why you don’t make `uX` an instance parameter?

I have changed the 𝓟 idRel to ⊥ and the ≤ to equality. The reason why I do not want uX to be an instance parameter is that one might want to apply the lemma in the setting where a type has no uniformity at all, and then along the proof put on it the discrete one. If you want I can create two lemmas, one with an instance parameter and the other one like this, with a usual assumption.
I see many `Filter.` in this proof. Isn’t the namespace opened here?

The two `Filter.nonempty_of_mem` on line 846 are needed because of some ambiguity, so I ended up not opening the namespace. Not it is opened and two `Flter.` are removed, I do not know if it is much better but am happy to keep it this way.
This proof is way too complicated. `𝓟 {x}` is an ultrafilter so `hα` and `hx` imply `𝓟 {x} = α`.

pullRequest.title: feat (Topology/UniformSpace/Cauchy): Add basic results about Cauchy filters in discrete uniform spaces

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/LaurentSeries): prove that Laurent Series over a field are complete
